abstract.p: Dr Leonard M Druyan letter on Dec 31 article on Strategic Weather Services's Internet forecasting business holds there is scientific way to forecast which specific days will or will not be rainy more than about 10 days in advance (S)

block.p: It sounds as if Weatherplanner has launched a lucrative Internet business (''But Is It Going to Rain?'' Dec. 31).
It sounds as if Weatherplanner has launched a lucrative Internet business (''But Is It Going to Rain?'' Dec. 31).

It is widely accepted by the professional meteorological community that there is no scientific way to forecast which specific days will or will not be rainy more than about 10 days in advance -- and certainly not months in advance. The best forecast for months in advance is to refer to the climatological probabilities.

Rain versus no rain for a given occasion is a 50-50 proposition. It is much easier to guess correctly whether someone's wedding will or will not encounter precipitation than to guess the correct numbers for the next Lotto drawing.

The article says that Weatherplanner charges $15 for a forecast. The company, Strategic Weather Services, stands to earn a nice income from the satisfied customers for making guesses equivalent to the toss of a coin.
DR. LEONARD M. DRUYAN Plainview, N.Y., Dec. 31, 1998
The writer is a senior research scientist at the Center for Climate Systems Research at Columbia University.
